newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Foreigners take $63 mln in Leumi sale. [CORRECTED 15:50 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Foreigners take $63 mln in Leumi sale. [CORRECTED 15:50 GMT]

text.p: Foreign investors exercised their full option rights obtained in a public offering of Bank Leumi and bought an additional 112 million shekels ($33 million) in shares and warrants, the Israeli underwriter said on Friday.

The offering for 15.5 percent of Leumi's share capital on Tuesday, the largest offering ever on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange, was 2.8 times oversubscribed and closed 12 percent above the minimum price.

Foreigners received $30 million of the total and on Friday exercised their options to take up another 112 million shekels in Leumi shares, Leader Underwriters said in a statement. (Corrects name of underwriter from Dror Shavit Ltd).
"With this the immediate funds raised in the Bank Leumi offering, whose revenues will go to the government, grew to some 670 million shekels ($198 million)," it said.
The offering closed at a price of 11.2 shekels for a package of two shares and two free warrants, against a minimum price of 10 shekels.

Leader Underwriters said the government could raise an additional 640 million shekels by 1998 if the warrants were exercised. At that point, the government's stake in Leumi, the country's second-biggest bank, will fall to 66 percent.
Leumi shares closed at 5.26 shekels on Thursday, the last day of trading before the Israeli weekend.
